nodes.bodyText: Same remark
Done
This modification is strange... You import something without using it. I'm surprised it compiles
I am using it. You cannot compile with unused imports.
Should we change the lossFactor to a double?
The IIDM api expects a float. Better to change it in a separated PR.
You should throw an exception in the other cases?
Done

Are you sure about the log level. In the CGMES converter there are a lot of informations printed, and it's hard to find an interesting information. If these logs are for debug, change the log level to debug.
Done. It has been changed to debug.
This is a bit uggly: why don't you add an isEmpty method to the Adjacency class?
Done
Is it allowed by the format? Depending on your answer, throw an exception or log a message (warn?)
Done. It is only needed when target P is zero so I have changed the code to use this configuration only in this case. I have thrown an exception in other cases.
You should extract this constant. Where does this constant come from?
Done. The MaxP attribute is not defined and this is the default value used in the current version. I have kept the same value in the new version. It is reasonable.
Assert for non null values when relevant
Done
Same remark about log level
Done. It has been changed to debug.
Are your sure about the i in simetric (I expect a y)?
Done
Same remark about log level
Done. It has been changed to debug.
Are you sure this is working properly? How is computed the hash on a List of String?
Done. Changed to list of list
Is there a design issue with Adjacency class?
Adjacency class is ok. I add a method to be more readable.
Same remark about the log level
Done. It has been changed to debug.
Same remark about log level
Done. It has been changed to debug.
Same remark about log level
Done. It has been changed to debug.

Why don't you assert directly the return value of the containsHvdcLine method, instead of storing the value in a variable?
This remark is global to this file.
Done

Replace by assertEquals.
This remark is global to this file.
Done

Are you sure about the log level? not a debug? not a trace?
This remark is global to this file
Done. It has been changed to debug.
What happens if only one is not NaN? Should we drop its result in any case?
Deleted. Loss Factor is always calculated. If lossFactor is NaN it is fixed to 0.0

Hi José Antonio, I have performed some tests on small grid case (with HVDC lines) and it seems that the attributes of the LCC converters are nor correctly set. I understand that the power factor is at its default value. It seems that the loss factor is equal too zero in IIDM in my tests, but the poleLoss in CGMES is not equal to zero. Can you check again ?

It may be linked to the fact that lossFactor is only set when both are not NaN in CGMES but I think it happens that only one side is set (cf. my question above). I think we should retrieve as much information as possible and only set to default values when there is no info.
Solved. Loss Factor is always calculated. If lossFactor is NaN it is fixed to 0.0
@MioRtia can you put your name here as authors ?

nodes.bodyText: @MioRtia can you add your name here as authors too ?
Done
@geofjamg and @mathbagu I think that MaxP should be always positive too as the active power set point ? It is not the case here. so we maybe have to fix the computation.

@geofjamg and @mathbagu I still have a question about PowerFactor and LossFactor that are documented as in percent unit (https://www.powsybl.org/docs/iidm/model/lccConverterStation.html). But it seems to be ratios in other parts of powsybl-core. Is it a ratio or a percentage ?
Done. You are right it was a mistake.
You have to remove the multiplying by 100.
Done
You have to remove the multiplying by 100. We made a mistake before because the documentation is wrong. LossFactor is a ratio.
Done

Done

should be DEBUG

It is done when this method is called.

This looks strange to me:

DC_LINE_SEGMENT are used for DC lines -> OK
AC_DC_CONVERTER are used between AC node and DC node (converter station I guess) -> OK

But I don't understand why do you connect all DC terminals to each others? And why this kind of links (if they are valid), are AC_DC_CONVERTER instead of DC_LINE_SEGMENT (DC <-> DC)

AC_DC_CONVERTED is able to connect one AC node with at least two DC nodes, so all three nodes are adjacent. These three nodes are connected bye the AC_DC_CONVERTER and not by the DC_LINE_SEGMENT. The DC_LINE_SEGMENT connects one DC node of AC_DC_CONVERTER From to one DC node of the AC_DC_CONVERTER  To. In some configurations there are two DC_LINE_SEGMENTS connected to one AC_DC_CONVERTER.
Consider log anything only if debug is enabled
